thread.title: Google's new 'popular times' feature could kill the queue
thread.title_full: Google's new 'popular times' feature could kill the queue

title: Google's new 'popular times' feature could kill the queue
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Jul 29, 2015, 11:49 BST - UK Markets close in 4 hrs 41 mins Google's new 'popular times' feature could kill the queue By Lauren Davidson | Telegraph – 7 minutes ago 123.38 +0.61 
The tech giant has rolled out a new Google Search feature that allows users to see when a particular venue will be busiest 
Britons are world-renowned for their ability to stand in a queue , but now there is a solution for those times when it's just not ideal. 
Google Search has rolled out an update that allows users to see "popular times" when seeking information about a business, such as a coffee shop or restaurant. 
The feature, which works through the Google (Xetra: A0B7FY - news ) app on Android or the Chrome and Safari (Other OTC: SFRI - news ) apps on iOS, creates a bar chart showing when a venue is busiest. 
Users can scroll through different days of the week to see which hours are more crowded. 
No word yet on whether this will help with Apple (NasdaqGS: AAPL - news ) queues... 
Google said in a blog post: "Do you ever find yourself trying to avoid long lines or wondering when is the best time to go grocery shopping , pick up coffee or hit the gym (hint: avoid Monday after work)? You’re in luck!" 
The tech giant claims the update will show "the busiest times of the week at millions of places and businesses around the world". 
To use the feature, search for a destination on the Google app on Android or the Chrome and Safari apps on iOS and click the "more about" button to open the venue's information card. 
People planning to pop in to Flat White, the Soho coffee shop, would do well to avoid its busiest hours: 1pm on a Monday, late afternoon on a Wednesday and pretty much all day on a Sunday. 
The busiest times of the week at Flat White in Soho 
Google has explained in a previous blog post how it collects location data from its users . Smartphones that have GPS settings enabled for Google Maps send anonymous data about their movements to Google, which pools it together and sends it back out to users. 
Not everyone was impressed though. One user commented on Google's blog post: "Add a feature that shows how fast the line is moving. Hope you added this for Disneyworld lines.﻿"
